issue.title: Add GitHub action to manage stale PRs and issues

labels.name: not release related
labels.description: changes which are not released (for example unit tests or docs)

issue.body:
Add a GitHub action to automatically comment on open PRs and issues, to help the maintainers close out older items.

Both PRs and issues will be closed after 90 days of inactivity.

This GitHub action runs once per day.

Based off Gradle's config https://github.com/gradle/gradle/blob/master/.github/workflows/stale-issue.yml

comment.body:
Could you add https://github.com/actions/stale?tab=readme-ov-file#exempt-pr-labels

for issues like #2709 that are super low priority but will not go “stale”? As it is a bug

i think this could apply to at least some issues

Openj9 is a fundamentally different VM to Hotspot
This is especially important with changes like virtual threads in mind that will have a totally different underlying implementation

pull_request.title: Continuous integration improvements
pull_request.body:
Fixes #2676

Does the following:
1. Updates GitHub Actions dependencies
2. Run tests on HotSpot, OpenJ9 VM,
3. Run tests on Ubuntu and Windows
4. Run tests on Java 8 (latest), 8.0.282 (earliest supported), 11 (LTS), 17 (LTS) and 18 (latest)
5. Compile with Java 8 and test on Java 17 (HotSpot Ubuntu)
6. Remove Java 8 requirement for `sourceCompatibility` and `targetCompatibility` (now resides in gradle.properties and just takes whatever J8 you have installed, or installs the latest J8)

Does not touch deployment of the jars on master, I found it kind of unnecessary because everything is done in PRs anyway and it complicates the build scripts.

This needs to be squashed before merging.

comment.body:
Should we prioritize testing across various JVM vendors? While it's generally a good practice, it does raise the question of which vendors to prioritize, as it's impractical to test against every single one

Testing with different Operating systems and a single vendor sounds more practical

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -10,15 +10,95 @@ on:
       - 19.x
       - 18.x
       - 17.x
+
 jobs:
   buildAndTest:
-    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
+    name: buildAndTest ${{ matrix.java.c }}/${{ matrix.java.t || matrix.java.c }} (${{ matrix.dist.vm }}) on ${{ matrix.os }}
+    runs-on: ${{ matrix.os }}
+    strategy:
+      fail-fast: false
+      matrix:
+        os: [ 'ubuntu-latest', 'windows-latest' ]
+        java:
+          - { c: '8', t: '8' } # Latest Java 8
+          - { c: '8.0.282', t: '8.0.282' } # Earliest supported Java 8
+          - { c: '11', t: '11' }
+          - { c: '17', t: '17' }
+          - { c: '18', t: '18' }
comment.body: Given that 18 is no longer supported, we should be able to drop this and replace it with 17 and 21, and possibly 22

issue.title: Test using other JDK versions?
issue.body:
Hi all, 

I noticed that the project is configured to test [using Java 11](https://github.com/graphql-java/graphql-java/blob/master/.github/workflows/master.yml#L20-L22)

Would you support building and testing (no need to release) using other versions? 

In particular, it would be ideal to check that the project works as expected with at least the newer LTS versions (17,21 at the time of this writing), and possibly with the latest Java version if possible (22)

I am open to send a PR with the same if accepted

Thanks!

pull_request.title: OneOf validation not being applied to nested inputs
OneOf validation not being applied to nested inputs

issue.title: OneOf not validated inside a list
issue.body:
When the type of an argument is a list of `@oneOf` input objects, those values are not validated.

Test for `src/test/groovy/graphql/execution/ValuesResolverTest.groovy`
```groovy
   def "getArgumentValues: invalid oneOf input validation applied with list of input type"() {
        given: "schema defining input object"
        def inputObjectType = newInputObject()
                .name("oneOfInputObject")
                .withAppliedDirective(Directives.OneOfDirective.toAppliedDirective())
                .field(newInputObjectField()
                        .name("a")
                        .type(GraphQLString)
                        .build())
                .field(newInputObjectField()
                        .name("b")
                        .type(GraphQLInt)
                        .build())
                .build()

        def inputValue = buildObjectLiteral([
                oneOfField: [
                        a: StringValue.of("abc"),
                        b: IntValue.of(123)
                ]
        ])
        def inputArray = ArrayValue.newArrayValue().value(inputValue).build()

        def argument = new Argument("arg", inputArray)

        when:
        def fieldArgumentList = newArgument().name("arg").type(list(inputObjectType)).build()
        ValuesResolver.getArgumentValues([fieldArgumentList], [argument], CoercedVariables.emptyVariables(), graphQLContext, locale)

        then:
        def e = thrown(OneOfTooManyKeysException)
        e.message == "Exactly one key must be specified for OneOf type 'oneOfInputObject'."
    }
```

issue.title: SchemaPrinter doesn't work consistently with OneOf versus Deprecated directives
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Using
```
SchemaPrinter.ExcludeGraphQLSpecifiedDirectivesPredicate
``` 
works differently regarding OneOf and Deprecated directives. With `ExcludeGraphQLSpecifiedDirectivesPredicate`, both directive definitions are removed from generated file, but with `OneOf`, also directive's usage is removed from types.

So for example
```
input SomeType @oneOf {
  field1: String
  field2: Int
}
```
becomes
```
input SomeType {
  field1: String
  field2: Int
}
```

This doesn't happen with Deprecated, they are still present in the schema.

Also I didn't test with other directives.

**To Reproduce**
OneOf Directive is added with:
```
newInputObject()
            .withDirective(Directives.OneOfDirective)
            ...
```
and deprecated with:
```
newFieldDefinition()
            .deprecate("This field is deprecated")
            ...
```
`SchemaPrinter` is used as:
```
new SchemaPrinter(SchemaPrinter.Options.defaultOptions()
            .includeDirectives(SchemaPrinter.ExcludeGraphQLSpecifiedDirectivesPredicate))
```

comment.body:
I think all three build-in schema directives (`@deprecated`, `@specifiedBy` and now `@oneOf`) should work the same way: if excluded through `ExcludeGraphQLSpecifiedDirectivesPredicate` their definitions should be excluded, but not usage.

This would be consistent with graphql spec:

> When representing a GraphQL schema using the type system definition language any built-in directive may be omitted for brevity.

Sure, `@oneOf` is new and not yet in the spec, and it might make sense to exclude it from the list of spec defined directives for the time being. But that wouldn't change what I wrote above with regards to `@deprecated`/`@specifiedBy`.

issue.title: SchemaPrinter doesn't work consistently with OneOf versus Deprecated directives
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Using
```
SchemaPrinter.ExcludeGraphQLSpecifiedDirectivesPredicate
``` 
works differently regarding OneOf and Deprecated directives. With `ExcludeGraphQLSpecifiedDirectivesPredicate`, both directive definitions are removed from generated file, but with `OneOf`, also directive's usage is removed from types.

So for example
```
input SomeType @oneOf {
  field1: String
  field2: Int
}
```
becomes
```
input SomeType {
  field1: String
  field2: Int
}
```

This doesn't happen with Deprecated, they are still present in the schema.

Also I didn't test with other directives.

**To Reproduce**
OneOf Directive is added with:
```
newInputObject()
            .withDirective(Directives.OneOfDirective)
            ...
```
and deprecated with:
```
newFieldDefinition()
            .deprecate("This field is deprecated")
            ...
```
`SchemaPrinter` is used as:
```
new SchemaPrinter(SchemaPrinter.Options.defaultOptions()
            .includeDirectives(SchemaPrinter.ExcludeGraphQLSpecifiedDirectivesPredicate))
```

comment.body: @arlampin seeing as this schema printer code was written a while ago, open to ideas. Would you prefer to see `@deprecated` always included, or not included in the schema printer?
